p: Filoviruses can survive up to 4–5 days on contaminated surfaces, and can survive in liquid or dried material for a number of days (Belanov et al. 1996; Bray 2003). They are susceptible to sodium hypochlorite, beta-propiolactone, 3 % acetic acid (pH 2.5), phenolic disinfectants, formaldehyde and paraformaldehyde, 1 % glutaraldehyde, formalin, lipid solvents, and detergents such as SDS. They are physically inactivated by heating for 30–60 min at 60 °C, boiling for 5 min, gamma irradiation (1.2 × 10–1.27 × 10 rad), and UV radiation (Elliott et al. 1982; Kurata et al. 1983; Mitchell and McCormick 1984; Mahanty et al. 1999) .
